entries.meaning: A short, quick movement, especially a brush, sweep, or flip.
examples: He removed the speck of dust with a flick of his finger.
She gave a disdainful flick of her hair and marched out of the room.

entries.meaning: (informal) A motion picture, movie, film; (in plural, usually preceded by "the") movie theater, cinema.
examples: My all-time favorite flick is "Gone with the Wind."
Want to go to the flicks tonight?

entries.meaning: (fencing) A cut that lands with the point, often involving a whip of the foible of the blade to strike at a concealed target.
The act of pressing a place on a touch screen device.
A unit of time, equal to 1/705,600,000 of a second
(dated, slang) A chap or fellow; sometimes as a friendly term of address.
examples: 'All that I have, dear old flick, is yours for the asking. What can I do?'

verbs.description: flick (third-person singular simple present flicks, present participle flicking, simple past and past participle flicked)

entries.meaning: To move or hit (something) with a short, quick motion.
examples: to flick the dirt from boots

entries.meaning: To pass by rapidly, so as not to be perceived clearly.
examples: They were quiet for a time, watching the fields and lanes flick past.
